org.team4213.lib14

Class CowCamController<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.team4213.lib14.CowCamController<T>

  • public class CowCamController<T>
extends java.lang.Object

    CowCamController is a very simple class that handles most of what one would do with a Camera. It reads the images and then runs a task upon them. The implementation is simple consisting of a few methods that one must deal with and is ready to handle multiple types of data using generics. It also uses Optionals to keep null at bay. Optionals also make it easy to not worry about an Image Processing Task if one simply wanted camera reading functionality.

    The class manages the Camera quite nicely and tries to abstract as much as possible. For more raw level access to the camera, you should simply go straight to the core OpenCV.

    Author:
    KrithikR

    • Constructor Detail

      • CowCamController

        public CowCamController(int cameraPort,
                        int fps,
                        java.util.Optional<java.util.concurrent.Callable<T>> imgProcess)
        Initializes a Camera Controller with a Port , Camera FPS , And an Optional Task to Run. The port and fps are int(s) whereas the Optional Task is a Callable T. The constructor is created such that a camera exist upon calling the constructor, as otherwise an infinite loop would be entered. One must also pass it a Optional.empty() if they intended on not having a task.
        Parameters:
        cameraPort - the integer to specify upon which port the Camera is
        fps - the integer to specify the frames per second of the Camera Read
        imgProcess - Optional Callable T that runs on each Camera Read, which the output of can be retrieved by the getDataOutput method
        See Also:
        DriverStation, VideoCapture, Optional, Callable

    • Method Detail

      • setCameraOptions

        private void setCameraOptions()
        Sets the Camera's Settings when being read. Current implementation sets the resolution to 320*240px. This method is private and is used mostly for clarity purposes when reading the constructor : CowCamController(int, int, Optional).
        See Also:
        VideoCapture

      • getImgAsBytes

        public byte[] getImgAsBytes()
        Returns a byte[] from the Camera's Image. This method is safe for usage by multiple threads. This should only be used if you want a byte array. If you wanted a standard image Mat use getImg() instead.
        Returns:
        byte[] created from the Camera's Image
        See Also:
        MatOfInt, MatOfByte, Highgui, ReadWriteLock

      • getImg

        public org.opencv.core.Mat getImg()
        Returns a Clone of the Camera's Image as a Mat. It's implementation is meant to be thread safe. If you need a byte array from the image use getImgAsBytes() instead.
        Returns:
        Mat that is a clone of the latest camera image
        See Also:
        Mat, ReadWriteLock

      • getDataOutput

        public java.util.Optional<T> getDataOutput()
        Returns the Output of the Image Processing Task. It's implementation is meant to be thread safe. Upon return the Optional must be unwrapped and checked for existence when reading the data inside.
        Returns:
        Object of type Optional T that contains periodic output of the image processing task
        See Also:
        ReadWriteLock, task

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Returns the Current State of the Camera Controller. It is thread safe for reading and returns isRunning, a variable that represents the run state of the Camera Controller. isRunning should be only writable by the class itself which is why this method exists.
        Returns:
        boolean that represents the current state of the camera controller ( whether the camera is being read or not )

      • start

        public void start(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService executor)
        Adds a New Camera Read and Process Loop to the Inputted Executor and sets Running to True. The method handles the creation of a infinite loop that is run on a seperate thread pool created by an Executor. Calling this method if the controller is already running is pointless.
        Parameters:
        executor - an ExecutorService that can be used to run the Camera Loop
        See Also:
        ExecutorService, readCamera(ExecutorService)

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops the infinite camera read and process loop running in the background. The current implementation does this through usage of a volatile variable accessable by the camera loop.
        See Also:
        readCamera(ExecutorService)

      • readCamera

        private java.lang.Runnable readCamera(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService executor)
        Returns the Runnable for the Infinite Camera Reading Loop. The returned Runnable handles many cases of Optionals not existing and is properly made thread safe. The method is private so it's only called upon at a reasonable time by the start(ExecutorService) function.
        Parameters:
        executor - an ExecutorService that can be used to run the Image Processing Task
        Returns:
        Runnable that contains the infinite camera loop
        See Also:
        start(ExecutorService), Future, Callable, VideoCapture, Optional, ReadWriteLock, Runnable
